body: Hi @coreyfarrell fastify-cli is only used in cli mode. It has zero impact of a running server instance. Outdated does not implicit a security risk. We @fastify/fastify will ensure that fastify is secure, fast as possible. E.g https://snyk.io is a better source of truth to measure security vulnerabilities.

At the beginning of this project, `fastify-cli` was a separated package. Then we decided to ship it directly with Fastify itself as utility to help users automate their services and improve the overall experience.

Thank you for the proposal and the analysis, but for now I'd say that `fastify-cli` will remain where it is :)

BTW, we might want to reassess this, as the decision was made long ago. What other thinks?

@delvedor do we have snyk enabled in this org?

> @delvedor do we have snyk enabled in this org?

Nope.

Thank you for pointing me to snyk.io, I'm considering using it for some of my projects.  I shouldn't have mentioned 'security' as regular bugs are just as much of a concern but more work to track down.  Unlike security issues there is no tool that will scan for known bugs.  Please don't misunderstand, the fastify team does a great job but time is finite.

@mcollina you said a decision was made long ago, is there a thread/bug/etc I can read?  I tried searching closed fastify bugs but didn't find anything.

I’m not really sure, can’t find it either. Anyway, what do @fastify thinks? I’m open to remove it as a direct dependency if everybody agrees. BTW, most of the dependencies come from update-notifier, so we can definitely slim it by removing that.

1. We definitely should be validating against at least Snyk
1. I really don't even know what `fastify-cli` does. I have never used it. I think it would be better as a separate entity.
@allevo optional deps still install by default.
